city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Holy smokes, this cake is perfect!  It's rich, moist, and not too sweet. The frosting is better than any store bought that I have tasted...so I will not be buying chocolate frosting ever again!  And I don't even like frosting!   Since my husband and I just wanted a few bites of a chocolate-y dessert, I halved the recipe and made just a single layer cake with no problems...except we ate half the cake in one sitting!  LOL.  In an attempt (!!!) to take away some of the guilt, I used a whole grain wheat flour for half of what the recipe called for and an olive oil/flax butter spread (SmartBalance) for the frosting base.  I also didn't have any milk, so I used a can of skim evaporated milk where called for and had no issues.  I was surprised at the general soupy consistency of the batter, but had faith that all the great reviews couldn't be wrong.  I did notice that you definitely have to let the cake cool thoroughly before frosting so that the it firms all the way through.  This cake will be a staple in our household.  LOVE, LOVE, LOVE it!!

My step mother LOVES chocolate and caramel and I used this recipe to create a chocolate toffee crunch cake with caramel cream cheese filling.  I made the cake and the icing exactly like the recipe, taking heed to stir in the boiling water by hand and it turned out so well that my dad was eating the extra without frosting.  I ended up making a 5 layer cake, using traditional chocolate ganache between 2 outside layers and the caramel cream cheese filling in the middle 2 layers, I covered the whole thing with the chocolate buttercream on the outside, and the covered in a layer of toffee chips!!! I have never had such rave reviews on my cakes.  I will be using this recipe for all of my chocolate cakes because it was also super super easy and quick.

text:
The first time I tried this recipe to the tee, I was pretty impressed. The colour of the cake was just right and so moist. The thing I can't get is why more people haven't said that the cake has a strange "oily" flavour to it. I tried something similar which needed warmed up vegetable oil and it had exactly the same flavour. It's a pity because other than that, its a really wonderful cake. Second time round I substituted the oil with melted butter and cut down the sugar by 1/3. Went beautifully with the frosting in the same recipe!

text:
This is the best cake EVER!  I use the Hershey's Special Dark cocoa to make the cake "better" for me (more antioxidants!), and instead of the frosting, I use a chocolate cream cheese frosting, using 2 sticks of butter, 2-8 ounce bricks of cream cheese, 1-2 lb bag of powdered sugar, 1 c cocoa (again - the Special Dark), 1 Tbsp vanilla, and a pinch of salt.  If you make a traditional cream cheese icing, and put it between the layers, then frost the outside with the chocolate cream cheese icing, it tastes JUST like an OREO in CAKE form!!!!!!!!!  YUMMMMMMM!!!! (that is, IF you use the Special Dark cocoa)....  Everyone who works with me requests this cake for birthdays, holidays, special occasions, etc.

text:
Very good!  I was looking for a dark, rich chocolate cake for a chocolate mousse birthday cake and this fit the bill.  I agree with JezthePuff, this is the recipe on the Hershey's cocoa container, but I've always liked that recipe.  I had a recipe for dark chocolate mousse that I used to fill the layers (3) and covered it with chocolate ganache as recommended by other reviewers.  Since the ganache and mousse had coffee, I followed other reviewers' recommendations by adding coffee instead of the boiling water.  Next time I may try instant espresso since we usually don't have the morning's coffee sitting around- instant espresso would be a bit easier.  The completed creation was simply divine!

text:
I've made this cake twice now and both times it has come out great.  I have used 2 9" pans and not had a problem with run-over and they are average height pans.  I have had the problem in the past with other recipes when I used a soft wheat flour such as White Lily.  For this recipe I used Gold Medal and did not have a problem.  I found the cake to be very moist but not heavy.  It was sturdy enough to split the layers easily.  The frosting make just the right amount for the four layers. It was very chocolately and not overpoweringly sweet.  My family was very pleased that I made them this for Valentines Day.  It's great with ice cream.

I will be baking this quite often, as my teen-aged kids and husband loved it! And I agree, there is more than enough icing, so put plenty between the layers, you won't run out and it's really good!

text:
Everything turned out pretty good. I might try to use 3 pans instead of 2; when the cake was rising it did make me feel uneasy as it looked as if it was going to drip out a bit, but it didn't. The only thing about this recipe that I would change would be the icing portions. I know it says "extreme chocolate cake" but I just put a medium layer of icing inbetween the two layers and all over the top and sides and there was about 50%+ of the icing left! Don't get me wrong, the icing was great, a nice buttercream-y icing, but I didn't want to use it all cause I didn't want the "I can feel my teeth rotting sugary high".

This is the best chocolate cake recipe I've ever used! I can't attest to the icing as the cake was for a different dessert without icing. I substituted freshly brewed strong coffee for the hot water. According to my bestie, her husband is still asking her to make the cake a week later! It's moist, nicely dense, and the perfect amount of chocolate...it can be used in many dessert recipes. Don't freak out when you've finished stirring up the batter; it will be incredibly thin. I was worried at first but this cake was the finest I've ever made. This will be my go-to recipe for years to come!

text:
OMG! PEOPLE! PEOPLE! Look no further for a chocolate cake recipe! This is the BEST Chocolate cake I have ever eaten or made!  Followed exactly except I sifted the flour and I used grape seed oil for all oil/butter. I used coffee at the end instead of water. It was soupy like other reviewers stated, and I was so nervous about it not cooking right. But it cooked perfectly!! I also added chocolate chips to the batter which made it super chocolatey and delicious!  The frosting was perfect also and had just enough. This is the moistest cake I have ever made!  The only thing I wld do differently is maybe not using all the batter, since it cooked a bit over and the cake wasn’t exactly even, but that’s ok.  Other than that, have faith in this soupy batter of a chocolate cake! You will not be disappointed!

text:
Delicious! My first cake ever, and I will definitely make it again. I followed the advice of several users and used coffee instead of boiling water, and I waited 20 minutes before de-panning. Had no issues with overflow, but I put baking sheets beneath the cake pans just in case. Also had no issues with breakage when I transferred them to cooling racks, but I used a parchment paper liner and grease and floured pans thoroughly.  I switched out the frosting recipe for another buttercream one. Next time I make this cake I'll try the frosting recipe that comes with it.

userID:
23407118
Display Name:
Tori S.
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6392962.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great moist cake recipe! 
I followed the ingredients completely until I got to the boiling water. We have a Keurig here, so I used a Swiss Miss Hot Cocoa K-Cup instead of coffee. Coffee over powers milk chocolate and this wasn't meant to be a breakfast cake. 
I chose not to take the time to make the buttercream icing and opted to use Hershey's Milk Chocolate Icing. For between the layers, I used Jiff Peanut Butter Icing and it really added a savory element to the very sweet and rich chocolate cake. 
Just be sure to make sure the batter is evenly distributed into the 9 inch cake pans and try to eliminate any air bubbles. 
*If you have a gas-stove like I do, I would recommend putting it in the oven at 325 F for 35-40 minutes. Gas stoves tend to have a little more power behind their heating systems (especially if they are a newer model) so a slightly lower temperature can help you avoid over cooking. 
I will be making this again soon. It was perfect for my chocolate loving family!

Just made this! Stuck to the recipe other than substituting the boiling water with hot coffee. Frosting turned out excellently, cake is very good, but really sticky, even after 38 minutes in the oven. I let cool in the pan for 30 minutes before turning them over onto cooling racks, and they stuck to the racks a bit. Came right out of the pans, though! Very moist and tasty. Didn’t rise too much or overflow, would definitely consider this recipe for a three or four layer cake in the future.

I've made this cake dozens of times and it's by far my go to chocolate cake.  I've made my own minor tweaks and have my measurements for ingredients down to the gram and cooking time down to the minute.  I won't share those because they're specific to my elevation and oven. Take that into consideration when planning for a party or special occasion.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed this recipe to the letter and let it cool for 20 minutes before removing it from the pan.  The cake is as light as a feather and very moist.  Just handle it with care. 

One change that I would make the next time I bake it, is the icing, and there's tons of it.  Slicing the cake to make four layers and icing the layers and the top was a bit too rich and sweet for me.  Next time, and I definitely will add this to my best chocolate cake list, I'll leave it as two cakes and use a ganache instead of the sugar icing.  
If you're looking for a super light, moist and chocolatey cake, this is it.    
Terry in Toronto

I've exclusively been making this chocolate cake recipe for years and I absolutely love it. Substituting the boiling water for coffee adds an interesting flavor. I want to try it with instant hot cocoa as well to see what that does. I usually skip the frosting recipe and make a chocolate ganache or vanilla buttercream, but pairing this with peanut butter buttercream has been a HUGE hit. You'll never need a chocolate cake recipe again if you make this.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Hey everybody

I thought I could try and help with a few things with my personal experience using this receipe, which by the way is absolutely amazing and delicious, I make this almost once every week. So as for me when it comes to this receipe 
1 cup = 250ML
1/2 cup = 125ML 
1/4 cup = to about 60 ML 
For this receipe I always level and pack my ingredients in the cups and after whisking all of the ingredients I use one heaping teaspoon on instant coffee with 250ML of boiling hot water then I personally use a hand mixer when adding the hot water and it comes out just perfect whether or not you do by hand or mixer, and my personal tip for the batter and baking is I use weight. so my 9 INCH CAKE PAN weighs about 115grams or 149 when using a home made cake sleeve which really helps level out the cake, and then my batter in total weighs about 1426 grams so then when it comes to adding the batter in the pan. I first Line it with parchment paper on the bottom and then add 604 grams of the batter to the pan or in total weight including the pan with sleeve on would be about 753 grams and then put in the oven for about 30 to 33 minutes and then the top will mountain a bit but all I simply do is put a flat plate on top then flip it over and makes the top completely flat and then do it again for the second pan and with the excess batter if you are making this receipe twice simply put the first leftover batter in a measuring cup and for the second leftover batter do the same and join.

text:
I LOVE this recipe, and once I make one, I can't keep it in the house (I get raided by the grandkids! :))  Even my mom, who "doesn't like chocolate" loves this cake.  I took another reviewer's advice and used a freshly brewed hot cup of coffee instead of the boiling water and, due to allergies, used almond milk instead of regular.  It was fantastic!  Also, I used 3, 8-inch layers to avoid overflow and sometimes, I frost them individually , cut them into serving portions, and freeze individual slices so I have it on hand.  I also make this cake for church pot lucks and there is never any to bring home.  If I could give this recipe more than five stars, I would.  It is the best!!

text:
This is one good cake recipe. In my case, I waited for over an hour to get the cakes out of the pan, and I put them in the fridge for the second half of that time.  I made this cake twice, and the first time I used the chocolate icing recipe given. It was very tasty, but with a vaguely bitter aftertaste. The second time, I made it with a whipped cream and cherry filling. It was fantastic! This cake will replace boxed cake mix in my house.

country:
None
text:
This is the recipe on the back of the Hershey Cocoa. I've been using it for years. My only changes are that I do not add the cocoa with the flour.  I put it aside in a bowl and at the end of the recipe where it calls for a cup of boiling water- I use hot coffee and add that to the cocoa to let it bloom. Then I add the hot coffee/cocoa to the batter and hand mix in. This cake is delicious and moist but this little trick elevates the chocolate flavor even more.

I also suggest using fresh brewed coffee instead of water for a better chocolate taste.

text:
Excellent recipe! I made it in two 9-inch cake pans and only added 1/2 cup boiling water because I added 1/4 cup chocolate chips to the recipe at the end. The frosting tastes like the stovetop cocoa my dad used to make.  It only needed 4 cups of my powdered sugar, but that stuff is never consistent by brand so just take it a cup at a time. Make sure that dang cake is cool before you frost it, and if you don't grease and flour your pans you will regret life

text:
I just made this for a bake sale for church and raised the most money with the recipe.  It is a chocolate lover's dream and very easy.  I made the recipe as written with one exception.  I frosted between the layers with the frosting recipe given (excellent chocolate taste).  I then made the Satiny Chocolate Glaze recipe from this site for the top and to drip down the sides.  Next time I'll try making the glaze with white chocolate and see how it comes out, it should look stunning (maybe a little less butter due to the white chocolate.  It will take some experimentation.)  This is a very rich cake and will satisfy the biggest chocolate craving! Thanks for a great recipe.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is my go-to chocolate cake recipe.  It is moist, but does not fall apart.  Sometimes I add some strong coffee or instant coffee powder to the mix (I compensate by using less milk if I use liquid coffee), which brings out the chocolate flavor.  It is strong enough to hold up to carving, as long as it is fully baked. 

 I made it this evening.  Instead of chocolate buttercream, I made a dark chocolate ganache with chocolate, heavy cream, raspberry jam and raspberry liqueur, which I used for the top and sides of the cake.  For the inside, I mixed up some raspberry jam, raspberry liqueur and some fresh squeezed orange juice.  I make it pretty liquidy so it would soak into the cake and make it moist.  (I put a border of ganache around the edge before adding the liquid mixture, so it wouldn't  spill out onto the side of the cake.)

It is the kind of cake that is virtually irresistible!

This cake came out fantastically moist, delicious and the frosting was creamy and a perfect compliment. if you have a Chocolate Lover to bake for, this is the cake! I did use the substitution suggestion of 1 cup of strong (dark roast)coffee instead of boiling water(it's suppose to enhance the chocolate flavor) You could not taste any coffee flavor. I also used the suggestion of using circles of parchment paper in the bottom of my non stick pans(no grease and flour) and the cakes came out no problem! if you follow the directions, you will not have a problem. Got RAVE reviews for this cake & would absolutely make this again!

text:
Let me preempt this by saying I'm NOT a Baker. But I wanted to make this for my chocolate loving hubby for Valentine's Day. I made a total mess in the kitchen attempting it but it turned out great. For some reason this cake gets more moist every day after it is baked. Today is the 3rd day after and it's better today than the day after I baked it. I tried to cut it into a heart shape which was probably a mistake as it was a bear to frost. (Did I mention I'm Not a baker?) I think had I warmed the milk for the frosting it might have gone on easier. Instead as a newbie, i just added more milk to get it to the right consistency. Keep it whole or bake in the shape pan you want and it will turn out better than mine. Hubby loved it and that's what counted! Thanks for the recipe

THIS CAKE BELONGS IN YOUR RECIPE BOX.

I made this recipe as cupcakes for a friend's birthday party.  The recipe made about 19-20 cupcakes from a standard 12-well cupcake pan.  I baked them in liners for about 20 minutes, with the cupcake liners filled almost all the way up to the liner's edge. They came out SO BEAUTIFULLY.  They are fluffy and light, despite how frighteningly runny the batter seemed.  They also popped out of the cupcake pan like a breeze! I will definitely be making this again!

text:
This cake was definitely not anything that other reviewers said about taste. I made this exactly by the directions - it was moist, which is the only thing I agree with. I brought for a potluck at work and everybody said it was too bitter. I tasted it and it was more than just bitter - it wasn't sweet and it had a strange aftertaste. I'm not sure what the solution is for this cake but I definitely think it needs more than just two cups of sugar in the batter and maybe not so much cocoa, since this is prob the contributing factor to the bitterness. I used regular,  unsweetened cocoa - not dark.  I won't be making this cake again.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed the recipe exactly. Both the cake and the frosting turned out beautifully! I agree with previous reviewers who recommended greasing the bottom of the pan generously. I had to de-pan carefully. Definitely run a knife between the edge of the baked cake and the pan before you try to turn it out. The two layers are not deep, so they don’t make a particularly tall cake. The cake has a slightly dense, very moist (I hate that word, but it applies here) texture and a rich chocolate flavor. (FWIW, I used Guittard cocoa powder.) The frosting recipe makes more than you could possibly need, but it’s a great recipe! Use a good quality butter. The frosting texture is really fantastic. It’s easy to spread but thick enough for piping, which was fun. I’ll definitely make this cake again, and might experiment with fillings like raspberry jam.

text:
This chocolate cake is wonderful!  I made this cake for Christmas and everyone raved.  It is dense and moist and the kind of cake that makes you whimper with pleasure - well it did me ;)   I was worried about the soupy consistency, but read enough reviews to trust that the cake would bake up firm.  I heavily greased and floured the pans and let the cakes set for 10 minutes on a cooling rack before removing them from the pans. I traced a knife around the edge of the pan before flipping them over and they released from the pan without a problem.  I used a white buttercream frosting  rather than the suggested chocolate frosting and the buttercream flavor in combination with the luscious chocolate of the cake was a big hit with my family.  This is now my go-to chocolate cake recipe!

text:
It was very good and moist.  My only complaint is the ingredients were totally out of order. I had to guess which chocolate, milk and vanilla went with the cake or the icing. Even with my guess work it was very good. I did switch up the butter in the icing. I used 1/2 cup butter flavored crisco and 1/4 cup butter. My husband doesn't like his icing super sweet and I find using butter flavored crisco, it cuts down on some of the richness of the icing.

text:
Hands down, the best chocolate cake I’ve ever had. I made this for my mother for her 60th birthday. Her, my 87 year old grandma and my 15 year old daughter agree that it’s the best. My mother has made basically every chocolate cake recipe that she has ever come across and she said she would never bother with any other recipe after trying this. All 4 generations of my family agree. One tip- I baked the cakes for approximately 5 minutes longer, after a toothpick came out clean. They seemed a little jiggly still at that point when I shook the pans

text:
This is a very light cake.....I'm guessing because of the hot water.  I did substitute dark coffee for the water (as recommended by other bakers).  I did cut the layers into 4....which was a mistake on my part.  Once I added the frosting, the cake collapsed under the weight of the buttercream.  If I make this again, I won't slice the layers & will use a lighter frosting.  But I loved how light the cake was!

text:
This cake is great, no doubt. However, this is NOT necessarily an original recipe. The cake itself is verbatim off of the Hershey's Cocoa box. That said, I have been making this cake for years. As other reviewers have done, the only changes that I make are using buttermilk to replace the milk and coffee instead of water.  I used to make a Chocolate Butter Cream, but I have recently discovered the simplicity and delicious-ness of making a whipped ganache frosting and it truly makes this cake a showstopper, plus it's not overly sweet.

text:
I made this as listed  trying to find a cake comparable to a business  in Greenwood , In. It rates five stars this way, but I added strong coffee  instead of boiling water  because it brings out the chocolate flavor. It is requested  by my extended family constantly this way and I have made it more than a dozen times since. Just be careful if you wait til the toothpick is perfectly clean it may be drier than expected due to the cooking continuing  after removal from the oven. Trial and error, I haven't thrown a bit out yet.

text:
Absolutely perfect chocolate cake recipe!  Follow the directions exactly and you will discover a new favorite.  Lots of compliments on this cake.  I put sliced, fresh raspberries between the layers and iced with a true French buttercream.  Incredible! For those that have issues with the cake not coming out of the pans, just use pam baking spray.  It won’t leave white flour marks on your sponge and it releases the cake after ten minutes (hint: if it’s not pulled away from the sides of the pan, it’s not cooled enough).

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this cake today AS IS and it is amazing!!  Extremely chocolaty and a dense yet light texture.  I HATE coffee and can always taste it in baked goods, so I did used the boiling hot water.  I greased my pans and used parchment; however next time I will dust them with cocoa powder.  The only change I add was to the frosting:  I sifted the cocoa powder and powdered sugar to ensure a fine texture before adding it to the butter.  I don’t like clumps of sugar or cocoa in my frosting.  I have 9” Wilton pans and used the batter equally between the two...nine left over.  The cakes rise beautifully and were even so no need to trim or level.  This is a keeper recipe for us!  12 servings is generous as a small slice is really all you need.  The frosting makes the perfect bite.

text:
Cake tasted amazing! Very moist. I only used 2/3 cup of cocoa for the frosting. The current measurements makes it a little bitter in my opinion. I also subsititided coffee from my Keurig in place of boiling water. Use Bakers joy to spray your pan to keep it from sticking or grease with Crisco (solid) and flour. Let cool for 10 minutes before removing from pan. If you wait any longer it will stick. All I used cake flour. I think the people who are saying the cakes are overflowing are using self rising flour. Also I made this in a 13x9 pan. Remove after 35 minutes. It may not appear done but it is. I plan on making this for my son’s birthday!

text:
The cake recipe is amazing, along with the recipe for the icing. Though I use just the chocolate cake recipe most of the time. I like my cakes dense and moist and this is perfect for it. Though.... The last time I made it (cupcakes for my daughters birthday), on top of the normal oil I added 1/4 cup of butter to the batter and a small handful of semi-sweet mini chocolate chips to each cupcake before baking. What I forgot was the vanilla!!!! I was terrified. BUT it turned out to be the best mistake I've ever made. Many people told me it was the best cupcake they have ever had. And to be honest it was the same for me. I chose to make a buttercream icing to top it, as my daughter had wanted them to be colorful.

userID:
23709978
Display Name:
Holly Branco
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

madeRecipesCount:
1

recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5393743.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
GREAT CAKE!!! I made this for my mom for mother's day and, though it took a whole afternoon (I'm a slow baker), it was completely worth it. My dad said it was the best chocolate cake he ever had, though he might've been a little biased! Be warned, this cake is VERY rich. I made this for 2 8-inch rounds instead of 9-inch like the recipe says, so I took out 1/5 of the batter (8-inch volume is 50 in. squared, 9-inch volume is 64 in. squared). I put this extra batter in cupcake tins. I made 5 cupcakes, but would've be better off making 6 since the tops flowed over. The cupcakes didn't need the whole 30 minutes, either - they wound up being a little overdone. But back to the actual cake: I wound up having it in the oven for  about 36 minutes and it was perfectly moist. I listened to other reviews, adding the 1 cup of coffee in place of boiling water and making sure to let my cakes sit about 25 minutes before turning them out onto wire racks. Frosting recipe is wonderful, too - so creamy!! I didn't split my cakes in half, leaving it as a two-layer (I don't trust myself to cut across straight) and it worked out fine. While frosting, some crumbs came up rather easily, but this wasn't extremely inconveniencing. Overall an amazing cake recipe that receives glowing praise from recipients!

text:
This is a lovely caked recipe. I would definitely sub coffee for water.

Variations that appeal to my personal taste: 
-buttermilk instead of regular milk
-reducing the sugar in the cake mix by 25 % (this creates a not-so-sweet and rather adult chocolate cake, well complemented by the saccharine icing
-adding a little salt and espresso to the icing
-shaved dark chocolate for the topping
-the use of cocoa powder and parchment (as per video suggestion) to the can
-make sure to cook the cakes perfectly in the pan prior to releasing them

text:
For a recipe alteration for high elevation, over 5000 ft, reduce sugar by 4 tbsp, increase eggs by 1 plus one egg white, increase milk by 2 tbsp., decrease baking soda and baking powder by 1/8 tsp each, and bake at 375 for 25-30 min.  Turned out perfectly in Colorado Springs! I only made half the icing because that amount would have been way too much. The cake is sooo moist! Mmmm

This is hands down the best chocolate cake EVER! Easy to make, moist, and the perfect chocolate taste. The only modification I made was using 1 cup of hot coffee instead of hot water. The batter was thin like others have stated,  but it bakes to a wonderfully moist cake. The only issue I had was the edges being crumbly. Someone suggested baking at 325° F instead for longer to avoid that, but I haven't tried that yet. Will let you know if it works.

text:
Best chocolate cake I’ve ever had. And usually I don’t like chocolate cake! As others have said, it is a very soupy, runny batter but it makes for a wonderfully moist cake! I didn’t cut back on the water at all- didn’t need to. Used 9 in. pans so no problems with overflow. Frosted with store-bought milk chocolate icing and it was a superb accent to the cake. Huge success in this house!

text:
made this for my fiancée for his birthday, used dark cocoa powder instead since he prefers dark chocolate, he loved it. everyone did. as far as cooling though, its 10 minutes in the fridge, 20 minutes if you're just letting it cool on the counter. cake was definitely sweet but always taste the batter before hand to ensure its as sweet as you like, i added an extra 1/3 cup of sugar because the dark chocolate taste was strong, i accidently put too much dark cocoa. :)

text:
This deep dark chocolate cake is fantastic and when they say it is foolproof, they mean it.  I made the cake and put it in the oven.  Three minutes later I realized I didn’t add the milk!  I rushed to the oven, poured out the batter and added the milk.  The resulting cake was moist, flavorful, and had a beautiful texture.  I will be making this cake again and again - but this time I’ll remember the milk before I put it in the oven.  I used Hershey’s Special Dark Cocoa and the flavor was dark chocolate and truly exceptional.  I used a chocolate ganache glaze and a bundt pan for 40 minutes.  Perfection!

text:
Awesome flavor.  Do not worry when you see the thin batter.  That's just the way it is and it bakes into a really moist cake.  I used three 9" cake pans instead of splitting the layers.  Loads easier.  I just adjusted the baking time.  I also used a cup of coffee instead of the boiling water.  It makes the flavor richer.  I also frosted the cake with a chocolate cream cheese frosting.  Doubly good.

text:
This is my go-to recipe every time i make cupcakes. I’ve made it 100 times and have learnt some modifications that make it amazing: 1. Sift flour, cocoa powder, baking powder/ soda, and salt together. 2. Instead of 1.5 tsp of each baking soda and powder, sub for 1 tsp soda and 2 tsp powder. And 3. If i have hot coffee readily available i like to use it in the place of the hot water sometimes :)

text:
Let me start with I am NOT a baker!  I tried it a while back when my youngest wanted a chocolate cake like Peppa Pig had on her birthday.  I tried this recipe and now my family loves this cake.  I make it for most everyone birthday. I did read the reviews and tried the coffee substitute. I really do feel the coffee does compliment the chocolate well.  I do like to change up the filling between layers.  I have used raspberry jam and strawberry jam as filling.  This time I decided to try to sub a quarter of the 2 tsp of vanilla extract with orange extract.  I was hoping a slight orange flavoring twist to the very chocolatey cake.  I did not notice a change so I might go half and half on orange and vanilla extract next time.  Overall it is a great base recipe to learn from.

Display Name:
Jennifer DeMent
isPro:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2990955.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
A warning and some options:
The flavor here is superb. We love them!
There is an issue with the recipe, as written though. I've made it many times. If the recommended recipe is followed exactly, there is too much (and I mean way too much) leavening!!! They either look like deflated volcanoes, or spill over the cups (sorry, guess I should have mentioned first, we use this for cupcakes - but it works out the same either way - if you read other reviews people mention the cakes falling apart). The cupcakes fall apart - too much crumble. So we use 3/4 tsp baking powder, if doing the original recipe. That said, here's an option if you want this to be more blood sugar and diet friendly. We use 1 cup sugar, we replace the second cup of sugar with 2Tb Sweetleaf Stevia Powder, 1/6 cup rice (cooked), 1/6 cup black beans (cooked), and 6oz hot water. We puree the beans and rice in the water, before adding it to the recipe. We replace the oil with either yogurt or applesauce, depending on which is handy. All the other ingredients remain the same (including - in this adaptation, use the full 1.5tsp baking powder). The resulting cupcakes are less than 90 calories each!!! That's low enough you could cheat with chocolate cupcakes for breakfast and still be on target calorically for the day. They still taste awesome!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614284.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Really great chocolate cake recipe. It is very rich and moist, and i would compare it to making a brownie into a cake with the chewiness and depth of flavor. I have made it twice so far and here are my adjustments:
- I use natural cocoa powder so I eliminated the baking powder and increased the baking soda to 2 tsp. The acidity of the natural cocoa powder reacts well enough with the soda
- Going off of other suggestions I substituted the hot water, but instead of coffee I used Guinness. It may also add a bit of leavening.
- I reduced the sugar to 1 and 3/4 cup 
- I increased cocoa powder to 1 cup - with this you may want to adjust the liquid a bit and go for closer to 1 and 1/4 cup Guinness.

I have not made the frosting yet and can not comment on that.

The best chocolate cake I've ever tasted. Extremely moist. I take the cake out after 30 minutes. Also be sure to allow the cake at least 30 minutes to cool rather than the recommended 10 min. time... if not it will surely crumble.

text:
As a professional pastry chef, I was skeptical about this recipe at first because adding the water at the end seemed odd when usually you mix the water with the cocoa powder. 
I made this cake as the bottom tier of a wedding cake, using a deep 12in pan, so I had to double the recipe  and it was perfect.  It came out of the pan easily and perfectly, it did take longer in the oven than the recipe said it would but that’s no big deal. Everyone who had it loved it and it stayed so moist. I will definitely be using this recipe again!!! 
Note: I did not used suggested frosting recipe as I had my own and would be covering the whole thing in fondant anyways

text:
This chocolate cake is what my mother used to make when I was a child. I am 71 years old and have been trying to  duplicate the cake. I have her recipe and yes it is the one that was printed on the Hershey's cocoa container years ago.  The original recipe called for lard.   I made it with  lard it was so heavy we could hardly lift it. Lol  I made this recipe as it is printed. It is the same taste as I remember.  I used a canned frosting. My mother always used a white butter cream frosting.  I will make this again noting that my oven temperature needs to be tweaked and if not I will cook it just a bit longer than 35 minutes.  Everyone that has tasted this said it is the best chocolate cake they have ever tasted.

city:

country:
None
text:
After reading some of the reviews I was skeptical about this cake sticking to the pan and coming out gooey.  I made this last night and the trick to not having it stick or being gooey (mine only baked 24 minutes) is to incorporate the hot water thoroughly.  Do not shut off the mixer and stir it in by hand.  Leave the mixer on the lowest setting and make sure the water gets blended in.  Your batter will be thinner than most cakes but it will make a fabulous cake.  Hope this hint helps!

I'm not sure why people low rate this cake. It was very easy to make and was moist, very chocolaty, and had no issues during baking. I used a 10 inch silicone cake pan, buttered and floured the bottom and the sides half way up. I also used good dutch cocoa. No overflow. No funny shape. text:
This is going to be my go-to chocolate cake. Sometimes my cakes turn out a little dry but this recipe resulted in a moist, delicious cake. The frosting was yummy too! (And I'm not a big fan of frosting)

If you plan to make this in two 9'' circular pans, this recipe makes nice size cakes, not too thin like some recipes. 

I doubled the cake recipe for my crowd but I did not double the frosting and it still made a lot! I covered my two tiered cake and a 9x13 cake and my kids still had plenty to lick from the bowl.

I recently put up some freezer jam so I added some between the cake layers and it tasted wonderful!

Perhaps the one time I made it was a fluke, but I was VERY disappointed when I made this cake. It was extremely dense and was not moist AT ALL. Also, it does have a much more genuine chocolate/cocoa taste which is to be expected in a homemade cake and I appreciated... just adding it for those of you who may not like that.  I definitely was NOT a fan of this cake... it remained mostly uneaten at a fam gathering... which, if you knew my family, that means a lot. Again, I may have just made a mistake. I have been baking for a while, but those inevitably happen. I like to think I did giving the mostly positive reviews that are being given. However, I just wanted to throw this out there in case you are like me and wished someone had said something.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674141.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Just a few things about all the negative reviews. I have made this cake more times than I can count. Never had a problem with it sinking.  Altitudes have a lot to do with cake rising as well as the baking soda. If the soda is not good anymore, you will not get the proper rise. 

I've made this and covered with frosting and fondant with out a problem. 

A few things I do are, grease and flour the pan. Also put a parchment paper cut out in the bottom of the pan. As the cake starts to cool, it will separate from the pan. I still run a knife along the edges before flipping it out. 

If you try and frost any cake before it cools 100% it's gonna fall apart. One thing I do is soak my cakes with a vanilla syrup, then wrap in elastic wrap and then foil. I then put them in the freezer and let them freeze. Pull them out and you should have no prob with decorating them. 

The only thing I do different with this recipe is use a different frosting. 

I have never had a complaint when I make this cake. If any of you are familiar with portillos cakes, I've been told on numerous occasion that this cake taste 100x better.

text:
I made this cake today, and I'm torn between giving it three or four stars. I give it four because there's nothing wrong with the recipe; it's just not to our taste. I chose to make this recipe because the reviews said it was dense. I'm not a huge fan of the fluffy box mix cakes--I want to feel like I'm getting something for all those calories. This cake is dense, but for me, it's like eating a fudgy brownie. I don't care for fudgy brownies, so I probably won't make this cake again. The flavor is fine. I didn't make the recipe's frosting. Instead I made a coffee-mascarpone frosting. I used 1/3 c. less sugar than called for in the recipe because 2 c. sounded crazy. I used coffee instead of the water as others have done, and I used 1 1/2 t. vanilla only because I added orange aroma. Those were the only substitutions. As someone recommended, I really buttered the pans and floured them, and hey presto! the cakes came right out. Yay! One of the remarkable things I noticed was how domed the cakes were when I took them out of the oven (although I didn't butter the pans' sides as someone had suggested to help cakes crawl up the edges and prevent doming), but as they cooled for 10 min., they flattened out just like a custard would. So, the recipe works, and it is dense and moist, and chocolatey. If you like fudgy brownies, you'll like this cake.
Review:

5

userID:
12618768
Display Name:
bluebelle
isPro:

followersCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4477243.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I just made this cake this morning to take to my daughter's for Easter dinner tomorrow; oh WOW!  It is absolutely THE BEST chocolate cake that I have ever made and I'm almost 68 and have been baking since I joined 4-H at age 7. Like many who have posted before me, I have never had a batter quite so thin but it works so don't worry about it or try to "fix" it because you think that it's too thin- it's not. You're wondering how I tasted it if I'm taking it to dinner...I used to bake wedding cakes so I trimmed off the top of each tier to make it flat and uniform to stack. I know...just a sneaky way to get a taste ahead of everyone else!  Anyway, I made only one change, which I know from experience that it enhances the taste of the chocolate, and that was to use 8 ozs of hot medium roast coffee (from the Kuerig machine) instead of the cup of boiling water. Everything else was as written and it was perfect!  I have no Wilson cake pans but used my old Pyrex round baking dishes that I've had for over 45 years. I greased and floured the bottom and sides and I also cut a round piece of wax paper to put on the bottom to make the cake come out easier. Simple. The cake batter did not run over as some had stated...perhaps their pans didn't have high enough sides. Not sure but mine came out perfect. I cooled for about 10-12 minutes, then turned each pan out on a wire rack to cool thoroughly before frosting the cake. I used the frosting recipe given and the cake is a "masterpiece"!!

Display Name:
Cate Sisco

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3534509.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this cake for my mother-in-law for her birthday. I will preface this review with a disclaimer that I am genetically incapable of following a recipe. That being said, I did not have  any vegetable oil, so I replaced it with melted butter. I lined my 8 inch round cake pans with parchment then butter and flowered the pans. I place cooled cakes in the refrigerator over night in order to make the cake easier to torte. When I made the frosting I replace the milk with cream of coconut. (I love a hint of coconut). When putting the cake together I brushed each layer with some of the left over cream of coconut to keep the cake moist. I also toasted sliced almonds and encrusted the sides of the cake with them. I topped the cake with chocolate ganache made from milk chocolate chips and the remainder of the can of cream of coconut. The cake turned out wonderful! There truly was just a hint of the coconut, because the cake was so chocolatey.

This is the best chocolate scratch cake I have ever come across.  I made this as written with no changes.  The moisture of this cake is  unbelievable and it stays moist.  I made it for my husband's birthday and he absolutely loved it!  He is a dark chocolate kind of guy but said it was the perfect amount of chocolate. userID:
21312694
Display Name:
Cara Maxwell
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
1
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614250.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this cake numerous times, and am glad to say that it is absolutely fantastic. The recipe produces an excellent, moist, rich (but not too sweet,) gooey chocolate cake that is to die for. Some notes I have are to follow:  
Your batter SHOULD be incredibly soupy and thin once you stir in the boiling water (slowly.) I was hesitant at first, but it cooks just fine and rises appropriately. 
If you are lactose intolerant or just simply do not have enough milk, you can substitute water and butter and there is no taste or texture difference at all. For every 1 cup of whole milk, substitute 2/3 cup water and 1 teaspoon of butter (softened.) 
Secondly, because this cake is SO moist, instead of a nonstick spray for your pans I recommend coating them with a Crisco baking stick. Just as you would use stick glue on paper, run it all around the edges and bottom of your pan. I have found this to work much better than spray.
And lastly, after removing from the oven, I immediately cover mine in aluminum foil for 1.5-2 hours and let them sit, undisturbed. This locks in moisture and prevents the cake from having the texture of "just another grocery store bakery cake." 
This recipe is super easy and the icing is great too! The icing recipe has always left me with extra, but dipping strawberries in it or frosting a batch of cup cakes are the two best things that I have found to do with the left-overs. I highly recommend this cake! It is AMAZING!

5

text:
I used 2 7x2 pans with no baking boil overflow, but I put a sheet on the lower rack just in case.  Cooked 30 minutes until the toothpick came out clean with some sponge bounce back. Next time I will use parchment rounds since the cake is hard to get out of the pan even with butter and floured pan.  I iced into a 4 layer cake, but I ended up having to piece the top layers back together due to sticking in the pans. I did use hot coffee instead of water.  The batter will be runny, but bakes up fine. For the icing I swapped out raspberry extract for the vanilla to add a extra layer of flavor and then topped with the crumbs that stuck to the bottom of the pans. Very rich moist cake....just wish I had some ice cream to go with it!

country:
None
text:
This cake was so good! Incredibly moist and delicious. I kept it a two layer cake. Since my oven is hotter than most, I reduced the temp to 325 and also switched the pans half way through between the bottom and top racks. I also followed another reviewer's suggestion of not greasing the sides of the pan to allow the batter to "climb" up the sides - I think this with the reduced temperature is what gave me pretty flat tops (minimal peaking!). I was low on powdered sugar so only made 2/3 of the frosting and it was plenty for a two layer cake that had frosting in between the layers. will make again, for sure!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I made this cake exactly as specified and frosted with a vanilla buttercream.  It is the softest, most moist cake I've ever had, and were it even one ounce softer, it would literally be pudding.  If you want an attractive cake, this is not the recipe for you.  I let it sit for 30 minutes out of the oven, then cut around the edges with a sharp knife and carefully separated the cake from the pans with a spatula.  I still ended up with the outermost layer of cake still stuck on the pan.   There is just no way to avoid destroying the soft, spongy edges.  If I were to decide to stack this cake again, I would definitely freeze first, and I'm not sure even that would keep it firm enough to hold its shape.  Next time, I'll just pour it into an 11x14 and tell people to attack it with spoons.

Oh my goodness. I was inspired by a wonderful man and refreshing relationship to bake a cake for his birthday. The kitchen is not my thing.   I try I promise I do but we never seem to jive. My cupboards are overflowing with seasoning and ingredients from dishes I tried to take on. Anywho back to this man and his birthday. Months ago he expressed his favorite cake was chocolate on chocolate and his favorite baker was his mom. Him being from out of town and his mom not here to do the honors  I decided to take this one on and have been eyeing the recipe for months. However I've never baked anything other than the refrigerated nestle cookies :) . I practiced on a box cake over the weekend and was pleased with the results. I paroosed through the comments for notes,bought myself a $35 stand up mixer on sale from target, rolled up my sleeves and took a dive headfirst. And guess what?!! I made it and it is DELICIOUS and there were only a few hiccups in the process...

This may be flawed logic but I believe it was slightly overcooked after I left in the oven for 35 minutes and I had preheated the oven for awhile as I gathered ingredients. I think 30 min would have been perfect. 

My icing was super thick and didn't have that rich chocolate color.  I improvised (yay me!) and worked out the consistency. It was so darn good and I was a bit over a cup short of confection sugar.  I think I messed up with whipping the butter and the directions about alternating ingredients? Had no idea what

MAJOR HIT!!!!
I wanted a three tier cake so just poured evenly into 3 pans... adjusted the cooking time shorter.  Hindsight- should have taken out of the oven even sooner.  Still delicious but the cake part too dry on day one.  Fortunately it got better and by day three, so flavorful. I did reduce the amount of powdered sugar so the frosting had an even stronger cocoa taste... but that was just my personal preference.  All the boys loved this cake and one even asked me what secret ingredient I put in it... This is my chocolate cake favorite recipe now.

text:
This was the first time in my life that I made a chocolate cake and this recipe was amazing! I followed each and every instruction religiously and also followed the tip by previous reviewers of adding boiling water with coffee to the batter. I also reduced the amount of sugar suggested in the recipe to half to suit my taste. It is very important to let the cake rest and cool after it is out of the oven or you might risk it falling apart. I used a springform pan and it was easier to release the cake from the pan.  I loved making this cake! It was moist and rich and my guests were blown away at the first bite.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm a novice baker and I have to say, this cake was easy to make and it came out perfect!  I made some slight changes, added a touch more flour for high altitude, and took the advice of a few others and added hot coffee instead of hot water, and for the frosting, I used half the sugar, only 1 cup of cocoa, and just drizzled the milk into the mix a tablespoon at a time (did not use the full recommended amount) and even that came out delicious!  Very moist and rich!  I'm very happy with the outcome since it was for a special occasion.  I will definitely make again!  Thank you!
P.s. I must also reiterate what others are saying about thoroughly buttering and flouring the pans prior to putting the mix in them and cool the cake, very important to allow the cake to cool thoroughly BEFORE taking out of the pans.  This will save you from having a broken cake.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Trust your gut with the batter.  You don't have to stick to the recipe exactly for it to still turn out wonderful.  (When making the batter, I knew it was supposed to be runny but I still added in a bit more flour than it called for and it turned out fine.  I also reduced the amount of butter and cocoa powder.   It was still very moist and maybe even a bit too much chocolate flavour.) I loved this recipe, but instead of making a large cake, I instead made seven cupcakes.  I reduced the serving size from twelve to four and it still gave me 7-8 full sized cupcakes.  Before you put it into the oven, make sure that you only fill about 3/4 full.  My cupcakes rose way over the top, and I filled them about 80% of the way.  Following other suggestions, I let them sit out for more than ten minutes before removing them from the pan and wrappers, because they were still a bit gooey on the inside.

If I could give this cake a dozen stars it still wouldn't be enough.  This is, without a doubt the best chocolate cake I've ever eaten.  I followed the recipe with one exception, I used buttermilk instead of regular whole milk.  I was a little skeptical after adding the boiling water because the batter seemed too thin, but I used two 9 inch pans and it came out perfect.  I waited the recommended 10 minutes, split each layer and slathered it with Extreme Chocolate Frosting.  Everyone was oohing and ahhing  over how moist and delicious it was.  What a great recipe.

text:
I loved this cake.  I did mix up the recipe a bit and made it with a different frosting: Chocolate Fudge Buttercream (also from this site.  In addition, I spread a layer of creamy peanut butter in between the layers because my husband is a sucker for chocolate & peanut butter.  I'm so glad I read other reviews first, otherwise I would have been concerned about the consistency of the batter.  It's extremely thin, practically runny.  But don't worry - bake as directed & you will be rewarded with the most moist & rich chocolate cake you have ever eaten.

text:
I made a double batch and used it to make cupcakes for my daughter's birthday.  I used half sugar and half Splenda and it turned out great. 
It was definitely moist and still good two days later.  The frosting was a nice surprise.  My frosting usually fails but this one was "me" proof. 
I had high hopes that this would be a match for a chocolate cake from a local bakery but alas,  my search continues. 
This is a good recipe,  but not the best.  
Still worth it for the ease of preparation.  My kids did most of the work,  I mostly supervised.  :)
I'll make it again.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I loved making this cake !! I did not separate into 2 , 9'in rounds because I did not have 2 :( ... therefore I had I think somewhere in between a 12 and 14' round and put all the batter in. I am very glad I did that as it held together nicely. After reading reviews it seemed to prove the best result the longer the cake has to cool I allowed the cake to cool for 30 minutes and frosted however there is way too much icing leftover that I wont use so that would be my only tip if you are going to use 2-9' rounds then that much icing seems ok but not if you are making only one cake. Also , I cut the sweetness of the icing and added water instead of milk and 2 tablespoons margarine and 1 tablespoon of tofutti cream cheese because I am lactose intolerant. So , I tweeked the frosting recipe and made it to suit my preferred flavor profiles and WOW ! the difference it made! This cake is moist , the frosting is perfect and I topped it with sliced fresh strawberries!!! SO GOOD!!

text:
The chocolate cake itself was delicious. It was dense, yet moist. I used parchment paper to ensure it didn't stick to the pan as per other reviews. There is nothing wrong with the consistency of the batter, most good chocolate cakes are runny prior to baking.  I  gave this cake the low rating because of the icing. It was way too sweet and overpowering for the cake. It has so much sugar in it, it actually made two guests sick with sweats and shakes after they ate it. I will keep the cake recipe and use a different icing.

text:
Love the cake. Like really really love it. I will make it a lot in my future. The frosting was a bit much for me. It is a really rich combination. For those that love dark chocolate this is it. but for my kiddos who are more of a milk chocolate fan it might be be too much. 

I still used this frosting (it made so much), but after frosting it and trying a bite I went back over the cake and removed almost all of the frosting so it looked more like a thin crumb coat. For my family this was a perfect combo. it was still rich, but not the im gonna get sick from 2 bites rich.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This cake is fabulous! My husband searched the internet,  read dozens of cake recipes and reviews before he decided that this was the one for his birthday,  and since making it he has decided that he wants this every year.


I followed the advice of previous posters and switched the boiling water for hot coffee, I also used 1/2 cup melted butter in place of the vegetable oil, and I used  Valrohna Dutch  processed  cocoa powder for both cake and frosting (the cake rose just fine).

I liked the taste and texture of the frosting, but the cake was falling to pieces because it was too tender for the frosting.  I ended up placing it in the freezer for twenty minutes so it would firm up and I could frost it. Next time I'll thin the frosting a bit more with milk. I covered the outside in an 86% chocolate bar that I had shredded. Now I'm going to go have another slice!

text:
Wow!  I made this today for my chocolate loving  husband's birthday. This recipe definitely holds up to its reputation on this site.  I have never made cake and frosting from scratch but do have cooking experience.  I was worried i would ruin it somehow so i was very careful about following the measurements exactly.  My only change was that i had three  8 inch round pans.  I spread the mixture evenly and watched them cook like a hawk as i knew this would bring down the cooking time.  (Ended up being approx 20 minutes) Be patient removing them from pans. ..the longer the better.  Taste testing the batter and frosting i knew it would be good. ...but it far exceeded my expectations.   My husband put on a show for us and literally hit the floor.  If you live around chicago, this cake blows away portillos. It is fresh and really unbelievable. (And no mayo, yuk) Don't hesitate making this recipe. It is worth it.  I mean jaws dropped can't stop talking about it, even after your full from it worth it.

This is truly the best chocolate cake I have EVER tasted. I made it as written. I was making 2 different cakes for graduation so I made the frostings and refrigerated them for a week. This required very careful handling of the split layers, and one did tear. Everyone raved about this cake and suggested that I make them to sell.

text:
The cake tastes good but you can't just use plain butter for the baking pans. I did and the cake stuck to the bottom of the pan. At first i thought it was the water but a friend of mine said that the boiling water for sterlizing the coaco powder. 

I would use any baking non stick spray or at least the old fasion method of flour and oil. 
The icing came out good but a little sweet. (I had to grind regular sugar down to make it powdered).

The overall cake was good.

text:
This was the same recipe as "One Bowl Chocolate Cake III", but it has a chocolate frosting. I followed this recipe, but I did not use the chocolate frosting. 

I followed the cake  instruction exactly, and it came out delicious. I bake a lot, but this was my first time making a layered cake. I was intimidated because I thought it would fall apart. It didn't. It was absolutely perfect. 

The cake was very moist and fudgy, and came out of the pan perfectly after 10 min. I let cool down on cooling racks. I slices fresh strawberries and made a whip cream filling for the center. I frosted the entire cake with a homemade whip cream frosting. I topped it off with fresh strawberries, and I drizzled chocolate all over the top. TOO DIE FOR! 

I will definatley make this again!

12014257
Display Name:
Shana Lee
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4248221.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have not baked a cake in 35 years, since I was a kid in 4-H.  This is an easy recipe that yields a deep, dark, glistening product.  It is just pretty.  It is moist. If I make another chocolate cake, I will make this one again, for sure. I used strong, hot coffee instead of the water, per some other reviewers recommendations.  I did not have a cake pan, so used a 9x9x2 baking pan,  and had batter left over for 6 cupcakes.  Baking time was 40 minutes, with testing every 5 minutes with fingers for spring, and a toothpick. Let cool for 20, after loosening the sides. Cake is heavier than box brands, denser, richer. Used a chocolate cream cheese frosting on the outside, chocolate buttercream on the inside, while still warm, creating some seriously oozey goodness.  Experienced no problem whatsoever. Easy peasy.

text:
I will certainly make this cake again and again, never buy store bought box cake or icing again! However a secrect I scrolled upon some time ago has been a big hit for chocolate cake is to substitute the water for fresh coffee, it brings out such a rich flavour. Follow the recipie and the cake will be rich and moist. Do make sure you greese and flour your pans well and let it completely cool before you try to remove the cake from the pans, or you will get a crumble cake.

text:
I have made this cake twice now. Both times I followed the cake recipe to a T. The cake is amazing; dense, fudgey, moist and very delicious. With the chocolate buttercream frosting though, it was too much sweetness for my tastes. The second time I made it, I used cherry pie filling in between the layers and whipped cream with chocolate shavings for the icing.  This really balanced out the sweetness of the cake, and I LOVED it. Everyone raved, even usual non cake eaters. Don't be discouraged by the thin soupy batter, it still works beautifully.

userID:
17321229
Display Name:
Deandra Gibson
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3145857.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm not a big chocolate lover but I do enjoy eating a really good moist chocolate cake on occasion.  I tried this recipe for my boyfriend's birthday and we both loved it!  He loved it so much that he almost ate a quarter of the cake as soon as it was done. lol!  I followed the recipe as given with the following exceptions:
1. I added 2 tablespoons of ground instant coffee dark roast to the batter. (Most people add brewed coffee but I think you accomplish the same thing by just adding the coffee grinds because you still add boiling water to the batter at the end.)
2. I used coconut milk and coconut oil to make it healthier and even more moist. (You don't taste the coconut though.)
3. I used Pyrex 9" round glassware with parchment paper on the bottom of the pan only, then greased and floured them. It allows them to transfer out the pan easier. Note: I also waited for 15-20 minutes before taking them out the pans.
4. I used ready made Dark Chocolate frosting instead of making my own and it still turned out Excellent. (Yeah, I'm a bit semi-homemade.)  ;)
Overall it is a must try recipe.  It is so easy to make and wonderful to eat!

text:
I learned once that a way to make cake even moister is to cover it in foil or plastic wrap immediately after it comes out of the oven and put it in the freezer for awhile.  This traps all of the moisture that would normally evaporate.  This is the best chocolate cake recipe regardless, but I think that tip makes it an outstanding recipe!

I made this cake yesterday for my sister's birthday, and it was a major hit.  I took the advice of others, & used brewed coffee instead of boiling water, & used cocoa powder instead of flour on the greased pan with parchment paper.  Let cakes cool for 10 min. As directed, & they skid out of pans!
The cake is moist, & frosting rich; this from someone who doesn't even care for buttercream frosting.  It is not sweet,unless of course you keep adding convex sugar,which in my taste would take away from the decadence of the flavor.

Recipe exactly as printed. SUPERB ! Mine took a little longer  to firm up in the oven and I was afraid it would be dry, NO WAY ! I let it cool and flipped it out, no prob. I split it an hour later. Made the icing and spread it, rinsed my icing spreading knife in warm water and smoothed it over. Everyone thought it was from a bakery! This cake cooks evenly and flat. No hump in the center. Greased and floured pan, no sticking. This has replaced my in choco cake recipe forever, its rich in cocoa flavor but not icky sweet .

text:
This cake was the most phenomenal thing EVER.  I did make a couple of changes.  As another reviewer suggested, I used freshly brewed coffee in place of just boiling water.  Technically, I used fresh espresso made with a Bialetti espresso maker, but in our household, that's just coffee.  :)  I also had a large bundt pan, and this batter filled that pan halfway up, so I didn't break it into two pans.  I did have to increase the cooking time by about 20-25 minutes because of that, but WOW did it turn out incredibly moist and dense!  Everyone in the house loved it and have all requested that I make it again.   This is a chocolate cake for the extreme chocolate lover.  It just doesn't get any better than this!

userID:
1706399
Display Name:
TJ
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5420378.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I too used coffee instead of water and hand-stirred it very carefully. I used two 9-inch round cake pans. The batter only filled each up half way so it was easy to place in the oven. They took about 30-33 mins. to cook. They rose up nicely but not too large so the end product is just the right sized double layer cake. I placed the pans on a cooling rack for about an hour, so they easily popped out. Then I placed the cakes directly on the rack for another half hour to an hour. This really makes sure the cakes are cooled enough for spreading the frosting. The cake is moist and has a nice texture but I think it lacks flavor. I made Creamy Chocolate Frosting by Tracy Larsen instead of the one with the recipe since that is  my favorite so it ended up being yummy. Next time, I will probably use more cocoa powder and/or add chocolate baking bars for added flavor.

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this cake in only one 8 1/2 inch (22cm) spring form, high 3inch edges, this cake rises like crazy, and buttered it and floured it, cooked it at 175C for about and hour and 15 minutes or so. As soon as pick inserted comes out clean, take it out. Turned out nice and airy and moist. I scraped the edges almost right after taking it out of the oven with a sharp knife and took the spring sides off, then flipped it on a plate about 15 minutes later and carefully cut in half and let it cool some more. 
Also I only made about half of the frosting amount and it was perfect.
Will make this again and again.

I've made this cake maybe 10 times in the last two months. My flatmates can't get enough of it, I take it with me when I go to a friends place, this cake is awesome!  Very easy to make. And I'm not even a big chocolate lover. 
Also the frosting amount is a little confusing, half the amount is just a tad not enough, but full amount from this recipe is way too much. So to make two thirds would be perfect.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this for my son's birthday cake. Followed the recipe as written and it was fabulous! I don't usually like icing either, but this one was very good! The cake was so moist that I was a little worried that it wouldn't hold up as a tiered cake, decorated in fondant, and sitting outside for a fall birthday; but I froze the layers before splitting, crumb coating, and decorating, then used some cake boards with supports between the layers and it worked beautifully. (Even after baking two days prior and decorating/assembling the day before the party.) The guests all said that it was awesome! I  had one guest tell me that, "If a cake looks good, it usually doesn't taste good", but that she was, "amazed this one tasted as good as it looked"! Will be making this again, for sure!... One last thought...I would let it sit for closer to an hour before removing from the pan, as others have said! I had one stick pretty badly, because I was in a hurry to get to bed and rushed it. I was able to piece it back together, though. Between the moisture of the cake itself and the freezing before decorating, it was still as if it had turned out of the pan perfectly on its own!

text:
This cake was amazing. I made it as written except - as per the suggestion of another reviewer - I subbed 1 cup hot (very strong) coffee for the hot water. My first time making a 4-layer cake and it turned out great. I split the layers with dental floss (unflavored) guided by toothpicks. I used "special dark" cocoa since that's what I had on hand. I'm not very good at getting cakes out of the cake pan, so I lined the bottom of my pans with parchment paper. Next time I want to make a homemade chocolate cake -- this is my recipe!!!!

text:
Made this cake for a coworkers birthday and it was gone in about 2 mins. Everyone raved about it and wanted the recipe. With that being said I did change a few things but tried to keep it as close the the original recipe without having to go to the store. First I used margarine instead of butter, second I ran out of regular coco powder so I had some dark coco on hard and finished up with that, I also used skim milk again because that's what I had lastly I did not cut the cake horizontally for the simple fact that I had a really hard time getting it out of the pan and broke the cake! I let it cool for 10 min inside the pan but next time maybe I'll let it cool a little more. Easy cake to make I definitely recommend it!

text:
I made this recipe once and didn't quite like how the cake turned out; I felt like there was too much oil and not enough cocoa. I changed the proportions a bit and the cake turned out great. Here's what I used:
1 ¾ white sugar
1 ¾ cup flour
¾ cup and 1 tbsp unsweetened cocoa powder
1 ½ tsp baking soda
1 ½ tsp baking powder
1 tsp salt
2 eggs
¾ cup and 2 tbsp milk
7 tbsp vegetable oil
1 ½ tsp vanilla extract
¾ cup and 1 tbsp boiling water

I hope this helps anyone who needs help with the recipe!

text:
This cake always gets rave reviews from my family, they all love it. It's super easy to make - one bowl, simple steps. If I could rate it a 4 1/2 I would, the only problem is it's very difficult to get out of the pan and very difficult to frost, as it has a tendency to fall apart. My best advice is to let it cool thoroughly, more 30-40 minutes than 10 minutes. Other than that I'd call it a perfect cake. Moist and spongy and bursting with flavour, it's a wonderful recipe great for anyone who loves chocolate cake.

Absolutely delicious! It was an amazing cake and a big hit with my friends! It was very moist and melting, a true success. I just hit a little snag in the recipe, the cakes did not "climb" the pan and so I couldn't split them; I didn't have baking soda at hand so I doubled the amount of baking powder, it might be the reason why. i definitely make it again as it was quite easy to bake and was truly delicious. Thank you for this recipe!

text:
I did read some reviews first and so I substituted a cup of black coffee for the water. I also reduced the cocoa in the frosting to one cup and the sugar to under 3 cups. Left the cake in the pan to cool for 1hr. I used 9" springform pans and the the cake did not stick (but that might be the tin glide), one of the cakes fractured slightly but I was able to put it together (it is a very delicate cake). The cake was moist and delicious, I could have eaten the frosting from the bowl and that doesn't happen often. It was a smash hit welcome home cake for dad!

text:
Wow ... just wow.  I’m done with any other chocolate cake recipes — this is now my chocolate cake. I’m a reasonably accomplished baker but I’ve often had trouble recreating the moist yet structured composition of a boxed cake mix.  Often the flavor has been good but the cake ends up being crumbly though it’s not dry.  This recipe solves that problem — it’s so moist, so perfectly composed — not too sweet but so delicious and chocolatey.   Even before I read the other reviews, I planned to swap out the water with coffee.  My grandmother always did this with chocolate cake and every single thing she baked was award winning.  Thank you so much for sharing such a wonderful recipe - you’ve given me something to look forward to baking and my family loves this cake.

I loved this chocolate cake! It's by far my favorite homemade recipe. It is dense and not too sweet. I was a bit taken back by the boiling water step because it made the batter look soupy but it came out just fine! I didn't change any of this recipe and wouldn't change anything besides maybe adding less cocoa power to the frosting. 

It reminds me of a cake-like brownie. If you don't like this consistency do not make this cake.

Very impressive as a birthday cake for a chocoholic! It was very moist and fluffy -- not dense like so many other chocolate cakes that I've tried. I took another reviewer's suggestion and substituted espresso for some of the boiling water. It did stick to the pan even with greasing and flouring, so I will have to try the parchment paper next time. I also ran out of confectioner's sugar (oops) so used a stovetop chocolate frosting recipe instead of buttercream, which was delicious. This will definitely be my new go-to chocolate cake recipe!

text:
This cake was so moist and it tasted great! I had to use maybe a tablespoon of butter because I ran out of oil and needed a little bit more to make it to a half cup. I also ran out of vanilla at a teaspoon but it was fine. I also used a half cup of coffee and a half cup of water. I'm sure the cake would've been just as great made exactly as the recipe states (I hate the reviews that say I changed this and that and did this and it sucked haha.) I topped it with flour frosting and used a little cherry extract(because of the whole running out of vanilla problem) and it was great.

Display Name:
Jon

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614242.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My kids love this cake and the frosting too ! I have tried it twice and did not have any of the failures that some of the reviewers did. I am not an experienced baker so I try to follow the instructions exactly. 30 minutes in my oven using Wilton pans, which are not expensive, is perfect. The cake is very moist so you DO need to let it cool at least 10 or 20 minutes before taking them out of the pans. I went around the edges with a sharp knife before trying to remove them to cool more. I elevate my cooling rack to let it cool better also. 

Have a cup of hot water to dip your frosting knife in. The frosting is fairly thick. Do not panick after adding and mixing the boiling water. It looks very soupy but ends up great. It is not a light fluffy cake. It is dense and moist. Very flavorful. I also have not had problems with it spilling over the cake pans. I don't know what is causing that problem for people. You will have leftover frosting if you aren't cutting them to make a 4 layer cake.

text:
This is seriously the best cake recipe ever. I couldn't believe how easy it was and I was actually pretty concerned by the batter but OH EM GEE. It was moist and amazing. If you sift the flour and the cocoa powder, it makes it extra fluffy. Make sure your pan isn't too deep or it'll take a long time to bake and it won't be as good. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The first time I made this cake, I followed the instructions to a tee.  I baked for the full 35 minutes because they were still slightly soupy @ 30 minutes.  Unfortunately, following the instructions led to me trying to remove the cakes from their pans 10 minutes after I pulled them from the oven, and they fell apart in a hurry - not a pretty scene.
My second run was more successful.  The only changes I made were changing out the hot water for hot coffee and making certain my pans were greased very thoroughly this time.  I waited half an hour to remove them this time... success!
This cake did not totally blow me away, but it was quite good.  The icing is to die for, and while the cake itself is fairly tasty, I found it a tad dry - I was hoping for something a little more moist, especially from such runny batter.  When I checked at 30 minutes, they weren't ready to come out, but the last 5 minutes seemed to take all the moisture out.  I guess I just need to find my stride on this one.
All in all, it's a good cake, but not something that I, personally, would write home about.  It's a nice staple, but I will be keeping my eye out for new recipes to try out.

country:
None
text:
If you are like me, and you read the bad reviews before you make the recipe, don't be afraid!  My cake turned out perfect with none of the problems talked about.  My cakes did not spill over during baking and cooked perfectly in 30 min.  I assume those who had problems used an 8" pan instead of a 9" pan.  I used parchment on the bottom of my pans along with butter and flour to solve the cake sticking in the pan problem.  The cakes came out perfectly after 10min of cooling time.  There was also no crumbling problem when I cut the cakes in half for layering, and they easily transferred around from cooling rack to icing plate. The icing was a perfect spreading texture, and there was no issue with crumbs.  I did always place the cut side down for all layers while I iced the cake.  The cake was a moist, rich chocolate lovers dream!

Wow! That's my initial reaction. For years, I have searched for a chocolate cake recipe that tastes like chocolate - not just flavoring. This is is! This is my new "favorite" cake and "favorite dessert".

text:
Overly sweet icing. The cake was good. I made it as directed with the one exception of adding coffee instead of water. The cake part of this dessert was good but I have made better recipes that I have ran accross. The icing had a good texture and was easily spreadable. I did have to add extra milk because it was very dense. My beef with the icing was it was TOO much. I started to follow my instinct and use only half the coco but I then second guessed myself on the wet to dry ratio and used it as instructed. The icing was EXTREMELY rich and that is said with a huge sweet tooth of my own. Cut back on the coco powder and it may be more to my liking. It is worthy of tweaking in the future to come up with a better less "extreme" icing. It was so rich it was almost uneatable.  I will stick with another cake recipe that my family enjoyed more. The icing has potential but not "as is". It wasn't a complete birthday cake flop, but there will be left overs.

text:
Move over Ina and Nigella this is the chocolate cake to make. This cake is crazy good. So moist so fantastic. I followed others recommendation and used strong hot coffee instead of boiling water. Otherwise made as directed, except for the frosting which I change a little and added melted 70% cocoa dark chocolate squares. I sliced up the leftovers and froze them individually and now I can pull out a piece of cake when I need it. This recipe rocks you've got to try it. I will never try a different recipe for chocolate cake because I found the winner.  Also I did not split the cakes, I reduced the sugar in the frosting by about two cups. I frosted between the cakes and top and sides. Plenty of frosting to cake ratio for me. Defiantly serve with large glass of cold milk.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674157.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Awesome recipe! I tried it twice with small alternations. First, I reduced sugar to 1.5 cups instead of 2 cups and did not add boiling water. I did add a teaspoon of instant coffee to dry ingredients mix, it gives the cake nice kick. If you don't add water, the cake turns out to be a little less airy and more chewy. 
Second time I followed the recipe exactly except I reduced sugar to 1.5 cups and substituted water with fresh brewed coffee. It turned out to be very fluffy, soft and delicious! 
Since my family doesn't like frosting, I'll be omitting the water next time I bake it, that way the cake tastes more like light brownie. But if you are making proper cake, I'd suggest to add a cup of fresh brewed coffee.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2014-05-28T16:34:23.607
