text:
Fabulous cake!  Like other reviewers I used freshly brewed coffee in place of the hot water.  I also used about 25% less sugar and it was plenty sweet - especially with frosting.  I did not use the frosting included with this cake recipe though, but rather the Cream Cheese Frosting II recipe from this site.  It's got a great texture and wonderful, rich flavor.  Yum! **Update 7/9/15: I have continued to make this cake for all sorts of occasions, getting rave reviews each time.  I now use the chocolate buttercream frosting included with it and it's amazing - dark, rich, decadent, delicious :)

This recipe is good. Boxed cake mix and icing from a tub is also good... and easier... I would generally still go that route. I actually halved the recipe and cooked up 1 x 8-inch pan's worth, which worked great, and fed 6 kids just fine. Needed 5-10 more minutes in the oven than a 9-inch pan since it was a bit thicker.

This may be the best cake I have EVER made!  And, I've made a lot of cakes!!!  ABSOLUTELY DELICIOUS!!  Definitely tasted like a professional cake. Made it for my son's birthday and the whole family loved it.  The icing was a perfect consistency as well. Just a note, we are trying to eat healthier & GMO free, so this cake was mostly organic with whole wheat flour. I've found baked goods often turn out differently with whole wheat flour, so wasn't sure how this would turn out.  I added a little extra water, maybe 1/4-1/2 cup.  I also used coconut oil. The cake did not rise as much as I expected, but it was a perfectly moist & delicious cake.

If you're just going for a simple single layer cake, this is great. However, I would not suggest it for layering, decorating or cupcakes.

text:
Super easy and delicious. I have no idea why this recipe has bad reviews. I am a self admitted "impatient" baker and a busy mom who has been looking for a homemade cake recipe that isn't dry.  This is it. After many cakes (my kids are 9 and 5), I will finally stop looking. Made this last weekend and brought it to Easter dinner with the family. Everyone loved it. I made the cake according to the directions in a kitchenaid mixer and then baked them in two 9-inch round pans. In my oven, on convection, it was ready at 35 minutes. I made only half the recipe for the frosting and had PLENTY leftover.  I made one change to the frosting-I substituted almond extract for the vanilla and this gave it an excellent taste! Thank you for this great recipe!

text:
Made this cake and it was great. Great flavor. I read the reviews before baking and made sure the cake was fully cooled for 20 mins or longer to make sure that it was firm and cooled down enough for me 
to start splitting the cake in half. I also changed up the cake a bit by adding cream cheese to the frosting and I used 1/2 of cup of Special Dark chocolate instead of usual unsweetened cocoa powder. Made the frosting really dark and perfect. It was the perfect chocolate cake for my friend's birthday!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I admit, I have never made a from scratch cake batter. I made this as cupcakes for a birthday party with a soy allergy and celiac's for another person. I substituted the following: coconut oil instead of vegetable, and with gluten-free flour, and just plain old forgot to use boiled water, so it was just regular water. It turned out amazing!!! I added soy-free chocolate chunks too (which I think were the special touch that won everyone over). I didn't follow the icing recipe as I was also making gingerbread cupcakes and wanted it vanilla flavour, so just added cocoa when I was done with that. Divine. They were a massive hit. And as you guessed- everyone could enjoy them! (thankfully no egg allergies!!!) Will be using this recipe again :) 

If you're interested in doing them cupcake style: I was a bit worried they would stick to the cupcake liners, but they came out just fine with minimal cake loss! Now, I can't guarantee it for everyone as I used a gluten free flour, but I'd risk it!

Thank you for sharing this wonderful recipe, RACH56!

userID:
11541774
Display Name:
Boris A. Bear
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

0
madeRecipesCount:
6
favoritesCount:
51
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1370413.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm giving this cake only 3 stars because I heavily modified the recipe. The cake is extremely moist and savory but the original recipe is one-tone and that is way too sweet. After tinkering around, I replaced the water with orange juice which I brought a boil with a teaspoon of cinnamon, added about a tablespoon of cinnamon to the batter as well. For the frosting, less sugar, more cocoa powder will give it better balance as when I followed the recipe exactly, the frosting taste extremely sweet. I also added about 2 tablespoon of ground coffee beans for a little bit of bitterness. I added a jar of marmalade in between the layers (so a layer of cake, a layer of frosting, a layer of marmalade, a layer of cake and frosting). I also crushed some Oreo cookies and sprinkled them over the finished cake. This gave the cake more flavors, as you have sweet, crunchy, some acidity, and a more flavorful cake. Great recipe base but I found my variation to have a better flavor balance and the result is amazing.
Review:
Rating:
5

userID:
13132167
Display Name:
caramello
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5829860.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
AMAZING!! My mommy used to make a chocolate cake for our birthdays as kids that I still compare every chocolate cake too. And let me tell you this one tastes SO similar to that delicious memory from so long ago! Unfortunately, we lost that recipe - so I am estatic to have found this one! I don't have an electric mixer so I have to do it all by hand. I made sure to beat the eggs well in a separate bowl with the vanilla before adding to the mixture. I also took the suggestion of strong brewed coffee instead of boiling water. Don't worry, you won't taste the coffee flavour at all - I personally dislike mocha (choc/coffee) flavour. I also greased the pan and used cocoa instead of flour to coat it. Didn't bother with any parchment paper - didn't have any - and it came out the pan just fine. I use a dark pan, so next time I would reduce the cooking time. Rich, moist and delicious overall though! So good I passed it along to my mom to try out!

by far the best cake I've ever had. just take precautions like heavily spraying down pans, filling them only halfway, letting it cook the longer time, and letting it cool a while both in the pans and out of the pans. it wont be the "hot out of the oven" when you get to it, but it is still warm and "sink your teeth into" good

I made this (the cake, not the frosting) because I wanted a moist chocolate cake, and the reviews were so good.  I followed the recipe exactly, and it was very moist - the texture was perfect.  But there wasn't much of a chocolate flavor.  The cake was dark, but the flavor was boring.  There was also a bit of an off-taste - I think from the oil.  I used canola oil, and it wasn't rancid.  Maybe another oil would have less taste.  I was disappointed, and I won't make it again.

This is the recipe from the back of the Hershey cocoa powder container. I have made this cake many times and it always turns out perfect. Last time I made it I used the dark cocoa powder and it was fantastic. It always tastes better the next day. 
 Make this cake in 2 round cake pans, not a spring form pan. If you are using a spring form pan you must wrap the outside of the pan in aluminum foil to avoid the batter leaking out.

text:
This was absolutely the best chocolate cake batter I have EVER had in my entire life, not overly sweet and it was totally moist.  It's sure to sooth the most particular sweet tooth...especially if you're a chocolate lover such as myself.  I made a couple minor adjustments.  I didn't have milk on hand so I replaced the milk with 2/3 cups of condensed canned milk mixed with 1/3 cup of water.  I used a cup of freshly brewed hot coffee to replace the cup of hot boiling water, and I used a chocolate drizzle instead of the frosting in this posting (as my cake was prepared in a round pound cake pan) and finally I sprinkled 1/2 cup of milk chocolate chips and 1/2 cup of crushed macadamia nuts on top after the drizzle. OMG, I will make this cake for the rest of my life, and will never use any other chocolate cake recipe EVER!!!  It's perfection!!  Thanks so much for posting this heavenly treat.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I've been baking and/or eating chocolate cakes for many years and this is the best one ever. Moist, dense but not heavy, extremely chocolatey, just delicious. I used Ghirardelli cocoa which I like  better than the dutch-processed kind, but if you just use a good quality cocoa you will no doubt love it. You sure do use a lot of it! I did two layers rather than four or the sake of time but it handled and looked great. Had no trouble getting them out of the pans. It didn't need all of the frosting this recipe makes which is notable in that I usually make extra. Your folks will love this cake.

text:
I made only the cake since my son wanted a chocolate cake with vanilla buttercream. I followed the directions exactly as written except I used cake flour instead of AP. I put the batter in buttered/floured 9" Wilton round pans. I baked for 35 minutes and let cool entirely in the pans. They didn't stick or break up when I took them out but were very, very moist. The cake itself held up well, split beautifully for 4 layers, and tasted absolutely delicious. This will probably be my go-to homemade chocolate cake recipe now.

text:
I gave up making boxed cake mixes a few years ago and have struggled to find a from scratch recipe that was both moist and had the texture I wanted...most were coming out as far too dense and just not satisfying.  I no longer need to look for a chocolate cake recipe...THIS IS IT!!!  Rich, flavorful, moist and just the right texture.  I did use another commenter's tip to not grease or flour the sides of the cake pan and I do use parchment paper in the bottom of the cake pan.  No sticking and these layers baked perfectly evenly...my cake looked like it could have been featured in a magazine.  So happy I tried this recipe!

country:
None
text:
This was the second time I've baked a cake from scratch and this turned out so much better than the first!!! We LOVE, LOVE chocolate and this cake exceeded my expectations! It's so moist and fudgey! Only thing I changed to the cake was to lessen the sugar amount the recipe called for, we may love sweets but not the extreme sugary sweets. I used 1 1/2 cups and a pinch of sugar instead of the 2 cups. As for the frosting, the only cocoa powder I had on hand was 100% pure cocoa and though our 7 year old LOVED it, it was a bit too rich and mocha tasting for my husband - which I thought he would have loved. Will def try semi-sweet or milk chocolate powder next time. I am so glad to have found this recipe and decided to make it. I may never go back to box cakes again!

text:
I have made cakes for years now, but only once ever before from scratch with disastrous results. This one is super! It is moist, but also light and springy, too. I added some dark chocolate chips in.  The batter is very very thin, so don't fill pans more than half way. An 11" round took an additional 10 minutes cooking time. This made an 11" and an 8" round size from the same recipe. I used a vanilla buttercream frosting with it. Delicious!  So happy to find a recipe from scratch that is good as I seem to be sensitive to the chemicals in box cake mixes and store bought cakes.

text:
Simply fabulous.  I bake a LOT.  I am replacing my old chocolate cake recipe with this one.  Moist, easy delicious.  This is very rich and sweet, so a little bit goes a long way.  If you are having a hard time slicing the layers for frosting try putting it in the fridge for a little bit.  It will keep it from breaking as you cut and lift the layers to stack.  I made it exactly as is and wouldn't change a thing.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614249.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This cake is amazing. I used my stand mixer and blended the dry ingredients first, measuring the flour the right way. While it was still running I added the oil and milk first, then eggs and let it run on medium high for quite a few minutes. When I measured out the water, I added a bit before microwaving. As it steamed out when boiling it came down to a cup. I turned off the mixer and poured in the water then mixed on the lowest setting for 30 seconds and then medium low for another 30 seconds. Since I only have 1 round cake pan I used a pie pan for the second pan. My 5 year old insisted we add some chocolate chips so we sprinkled a handful on top right before baking. Since I have a tiny oven I put one on the top shelf and another on the bottom, baking for 17 minutes and then switching for another 15. They came out perfectly. Next time I will try using coffee instead of water like one reviewer suggested. I would like to see if it would work with a substitute for the eggs, so we can lick the beaters and not waste any chocolate. The color was very dark, the texture was fluffy and moist, and we ate half of it before we had a chance to make the frosting. Super yummy and easy! I will make this cake again and again.

text:
This cake turned out great--and I read the instructions too fast and dumped the boiling water in with the other wet ingredients. Oops. Still great!
Here's how to avoid sticking: Grease the pans, then put cut-to-fit circles of parchment paper in the bottoms, grease them, and flour the whole thing. The cakes will turn out beautifully and the parchment paper peels off.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Okay, I read a lot of reviews for this recipe and I seen that people had trouble getting it out of the pans or that the batter over flowed in the oven. Honestly, I was starting to worry about making this cake because I thought it was going to turn out really bad! I made a few changes to the recipe, but I think I could have left it the way it was because I believe I have a recipe a lot like this one. But anyway, I used one cup of white sugar and one cup of brown sugar, one cup of coffee instead of water, and I melted 1/2 a cup of chocolate and mixed it in too. The cake tuned out really moist, and sooo good! I didn't fill my pans quite as full as I would normally because I didn't want a mess like others had, but that didn't happen, and they came out of the pans with no problem. I think it would have been good even if I hadn't changed the recipe. I'm making it for someone's retirement party it was that good!

text:
It was an absolute LOVE at the birthday party that I baked this cake for. I actually had run out of confectioners sugar by 1 cup, for the icing. I substituted with a cup of standard granulated sugar. It turned out a bit crunchy and gritty. However, the guests were enthused, saying that they loved the crunchiness and the little crystal spurts of sugar in the icing. So if you think your guests will like the extra crunch and crystal, go for that last cup of sugar in the icing to be granulated. ;)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This cake was a hit! I used almond milk instead of regular milk, apple sauce instead of vegetable oil and tea instead of plain old boiling water. The tea I used is David's Tea, Chocolate Rocket flavour. It definitely added deliciousness! I used Green and Blacks' cocoa cuz it's a personal favourite. For the icing I used a homemade white chocolate cream icing which complimented it well. I cooked it in a single bundt cake pan for about 25 minutes on a slightly lower temperature to avoid burning the top. It was super moist and scrumptious!

text:
Espresso-Cinnamon variation.  Substitute one cup strong-brewed coffee or espresso for the boiling water.  Add one teaspoon to one tablespoon of cinnamon to the frosting (depending on how "spicy" you like your icing).  After frosting, lightly dust with cinnamon and powdered sugar.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was my first time making a cake from scratch, and first, let me say: The cake tastes awesome. The icing and cake flavors go very well together. Truly devlish!  

For the presentation: I was thrown off by how moist the cake is. It was sticky! Adding the boiling water really makes a difference in the texture. It was so sticky, I had trouble removing it from the greased and floured pan.  Also, the cake stuck to my spoon when putting on the icing, even though it was completely cooled.  I was also surprised with the amount of cake the batter made.  I could have used double the cake for the amount of icing!

All in all, this is a keeper.  As I improve on my technique, I'm sure I'll be able to perfect the process.  This was a good start!

text:
This is absolutely delicious. So moist and so delicious. I substituted 1/2 cup of applesauce for the oil because I don't like to use oil in any recipe and it turned out perfect. I also substituted water for the milk because we don't drink milk (and thus never have any) and it was fine. I use Ghiradelli cocoa powder. I make this every time I want to make a cake. I do 2 9-inch layers and there is WAY too much frosting, and I load it on, but I haven't figured out exactly how much is perfect (half the frosting recipe is too little). We just end up saving it - it is very fudgelike.

country:
None
text:
Great chocolate cake! Moist with a nice crumb...I got two layers out of this recipe, and it would leave really thin layers if I were to torte it. I cut the recipe for the frosting by 2/3, and used it only for the top and piping around the filled center, which was ganache. Rich and delicious. Will use the cake portion again, for sure.

Update: I let this sit overnight in the fridge and upped it from 4 to 5 stars for the cake portion. Letting it sit really brought out the flavor, and the cake itself is just as good or better than any bakery cake. I've been looking for a chocolate cake recipe that is not so dense and heavy or dry, and this fits all three. Definitely a go-to cake recipe.

MIKIESHERREE

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674154.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I halved the recipe and made 12 cupcakes.  They definitely rise well - though they flattened out a bit while cooling.  The tops were pretty crispy on day one, but softened up to normal cake texture by day two.  The texture of the rest of the cupcake (besides the top) was soft/fairly moist.  The taste was pretty standard chocolate cake - not amazing, but pretty tasty under a good frosting - I used a mint cream cheese frosting, rather than the one in the recipe.  I also stirred about a tsp of instant coffee into the boiling water and added about 1/2 tsp imitation butter flavor with the vanilla (I add that to most cakes - esp ones that don't contain butter - it seems to give a richer, more professional taste).  I'd make this again in a pinch because the ingredients are things I always have on hand, the batter comes together quickly, and the taste was pretty good.  I'm still searching for a five-star chocolate cake recipe, though.

I thought these cupcakes were great, I was shocked when I added to boiling water. I thought something went horribly wrong. But thats how it is suppose to be I guess. I just put them in a bowl with a spout and poured it into the cupcake liners. I found that pouring this batter was much easier than spooning regular batter. The tops of my cupcakes turned out crunchy, which everybody liked. I made Crème de menthe frosting with these. Everybody loved these, including my picky boyfriend who hates anything that isnt a chocolate chip cookie.

text:
This cake is truly superb - very moist, very chocolately, rich and creamy icing.  I've never tasted a chocolate cake this good, seriously!  The only changes I made were switching the cup of boiling water for a cup of hot brewed coffee, and I had to bake for 50 minutes before a toothpick came out clean.  I had no spillage at all when I divided the batter between 2 layer cake pans.  Perfect amount of icing to complete the 4 layers with generous amounts.  I'd give this 10 stars if I could - truly scrumptious!

text:
It's pretty hard to come across a moist, delicious cake recipe that doesn't use prepackaged cake mix and pudding. I made one little change to this recipe, and that was melting 1/4 cup of chocolate chips into the boiling water before mixing it in with the batter. The cake turned out wonderfully (as with other reviewers, I was concerned about the batter being too watery) and it tasted like the cupcakes you buy for $5 bucks each. Awesome recipe!

text:
Made this cake last week for a friend's birthday, and yes, it's very moist and delicious.

As suggested by others, I added 1 cup of hot coffee (instant vanilla coffee), reduced the sugar to 1.5 cups instead of the 2 cups as per the recipe and used unsalted melted butter instead of the oil.

I frosted it with a boiled icing and sprinkled the top and 4 layers (I sliced the cakes horizontally in 2) with toasted coconut and skor bits.  Everyone loved this cake - will be making this cake again.

text:
I made this cake for my boyfriend's birthday. He told me he wanted a chocolatey cake and that's exactly what this is! It's super easy to make and the frosting takes almost exactly as long to make as the cake does to bake so you don't have to worry about doing two things at once. 

I do have a TIP though for you frosting makers: if your frosting is too hard to mix, try using your hands. Squishing the frosting between your fingers really helps it to mix together.  :)

I made this cake for my husband's birthday. It was a huge success!!! One of his called weeks after to say he had dreamed about the cake I made. It was rich and moist and delicious. The boiling water is probably what did it. 
I think it is important to not cheap out on the cocoa, invest in a good one.

This will be by default chocolate cake from now on!!!

I made this into cupcakes without the chocolate frosting that was suggested.  I had some peppermint frosting that I bought during Christmas that I thought would taste really yummy...and it did!

The batter does look sort of soupy once the boiling water is added, but it cooks just great. I also hand mixed every ingredient as I put it into the bowl.  Super tasty!  My daughter said I should make them every day!!  :)

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I'm with Eli on this one.  This is the only recipe I use for chocolate cake and you must follow the instructions to the letter.  With scratch cakes; unlike the boxed cake varieties which allow more room for error, you must be pretty precise.  Do test the cake to see if it is done and I usually take the cake out when a few crumbs adhere to the tooth pic.  If you over bake the cake you will have a dry cake on your hands and no amount of frosting will help.  I also substitute the boiling water for coffee which really enhances the chocolate flavor.  Wonderful moist cake.

First I have to point out that while the cake was baking, the oven was mistakenly turned off.  I don't know if I made the mistake or someone else in the household did it. ( I have a tendency to forget to turn the oven off)   Even though the cake was a bit dry (my fault) it was still very good. For someone who doesn't eat a lot of chocolate it is a very rich cake, but also very good.  Took care of my craving quite nicely.

text:
Love love love this cake!! I make this for everything and always get asked for the recipe (in between full-mouthed mumbles of 'omg'). This takes a lot of will power to not eat all in one go!

I don't use this recipes frosting though, I think sticky caramel compliments it much better, making it super sweet & rich. I just use the tinned caramel and melt it down with some cream. I also add in dessicated coconut and/or copped nuts to the caramel.

Makes a great slice or cup cake as well . Enjoy.

text:
This recipe was really great! I was looking for a recipe that used cocoa powder so that I didnt have to go to the store before I baked! Out of my laziness I found this gem of a recipe! So good, moist and delicious aspecially because I thought I might have to sacrifice some flavor for not using bakers chocolate, but that was not the case at all! I will say the frosting seemed like it wasnt coming together at first and I added a little milk (maybe a teaspoon) and then just kept mixing it and it was perfect! Might have been fine even without the milk if I would have been more patient! Everyone loved this and it was gone in a day! I will say we cuut the frosting in half because I wasnt filling the cake with it, and it was still too much, but that just meant we had some extra to eat!If you want a cake recipe to keep forever, this is it!

text:
An absolutely wonderful recipe! I made it for a going away party for my friend Josh, and I followed the advice of some of the reviewers on here and used a cup of strong hot coffee rather than hot water, which turned out fabulously. I frosted the cake and then decorated it with white frosting designs topped with M&M's. I would just advise people as we're getting into summer months to be super careful when frosting this in a warm room, the frosting started to melt for me and my top layer slid a little bit. I was able to carefully slide it back into place, and then I had it sit in the fridge for a while before I took it out to serve. Amazing recipe, though!

text:
I wanted a nice moist chocolate cupcake recipe. This is it. It tastes very good and its moist. However, I made these as cupcakes, and I was a little hesitant. I peeked in the oven and saw they were rising like normal cupcakes, so I didn't worry about it. Then, after I took it out, they went flat and in. These are great to put frosting on, but not too attractive by themselves. In addition, I added "instant coffee crystals" to the boiling water, to make mocha cupcakes. They turned out alright, but I suggest adding a cup of plain coffee instead.

text:
This recipe is simply awesome!!!   The cakes came out super moist and not too sweet.  I used half the ingredients to make one batch of cupcakes for my 4 year old.  I filled each cup to about 3/4 full, baked at 350 degree for 15-18 minutes, until toothpick comes out clean.  Makes a perfect dozen.  They puffed up very nicely, and still very moist the next day.  They're as good as, if not better, than some bakery cupcakes.  I did not make the frosting this time, will try it next time.  This is definitely a keeper!

text:
This recipe is GREAT! I made cupcakes instead of a layer cake and they turned out perfectly. I followed the recipe as written and while the batter is VERY watery, it bakes up just fine. I did not fill cups as full as I normally would, based on other reviews but could have as they were small since they did not raise much (meaning they would not have run over like others were saying). I baked at 350 for 12 minutes and they came out perfectly. DO NOT use Pam for pans, grease and flour as stated in recipe. I halved the frosting and still had quite a bit left over. I am making another batch today, they are that good. Thanks! :)

text:
AMAZING!!! The best chocolate cake I have ever tasted. I was a little skeptical about the icing, but it goes perfectly with the cake. I however halved the icing recipe and didn't use all the cocoa powder or the milk. I only halved it because I don't like a lot of icing on my cake. Half the recipe makes the perfect amount. I also recommend sifting all the dry ingredients. For the cake and icing. I didn't and  my icing had lumps. Still good, but next time I'll sift. All in all an amazing cake.

text:
This cake was fantastic.  I followed the instructions exactly and made it into 4 layers.  The only thing I did different was not using as much oil.  I did a test run the day before using cake flour and the full amount of oil but it refused to come out of the pan.  The next day I used regular all purpose flour and slightly less oil and it came out of the pan.  Baking time definitely seems to be off as it took a lot longer than I anticipated and had many holes poked in it from testing.  Good thing frosting covered that up.  My husband drenched his pieces in Hazelnut coffee for breakfast and inhaled the whole cake in a matter of a couple days!

text:
I followed the recipe exact, except for using hot coffee in place of boiling water like someone else suggested. I too was skeptical and almost didnt add all the coffee because the batter started to look unbelievably runny, but I did it anyway. I baked for about 35 minutes in 2-9 inch rounds and it was perfect. I greased the pans generously with bakers joy, and after resting for 10 minutes in the pans, they came out beautifully. The only reason I give this recipe 4 stars instead of 5 was the icing. The cake was perfect, but the icing was grainy. I think it has way too much cocoa powder in it. May just be my personal preference. I will bake the cake many times again, but find a new icing recipe to accompany it.

Amazing! I followed one reviewer's advice and replaced the boiling water with a cup of hot coffee and it only added to the flavour (coffee is like vanilla extract in that way). Don't be afraid of the soupy batter after adding the water/coffee... the cake will cook up just fine and will be beautifully moist when it's finished cooking. I made three 8-inch round layers and topped them with a homemade chocolate buttercream icing. It got rave reviews from everyone at the table, and many went for seconds. Thanks so much for a great recipe!

amazing!!! The cake was absolutely moist! I placed it in a small cake pan, and because I wanted to make to cake I separated the mixture, filled the pan 1/2 full. I shouldn't have because the cake turned out to be too thin, i should have filled the pan 2/3 full. But no big deal. It still turned out great! text:
Fantastic! I tripled this recipe and made a 4 layer 9" round and a 9x13. I only had to double the frosting, since the 9x13 was only one layer. The batter is super thin and it baked much longer than 35 minutes (maybe 45 for the rounds and 60 min. for the 9x13, until a toothpick came out clean) in my convection oven, but the results are great. It was rich, moist, and super chocolaty. Several people asked for the recipe.

text:
This cake came out great!!! It was moist but not falling apart. The batter was very "watery" but baked up perfectly. I had an odd issue with one cake baking faster then the other. It very well could have been an issue with my oven. The frosting I found to be a little daunting to make because I do not have a stand mixer. Thats A LOT of 10X sugar to beat up and I think I might even up the vanilla a tad, maybe an additional 1/4 tsp. or possibly a little more cocoa powder. To me it seemed to taste an awful lot like the 10X sugar more then anything. Ill have to tinker with it some. It didn't bother anyone else. The cake disappeared very quickly. Small slices are highly recommended!! And taste fantastic the days after baking!!

I am having a hard time finding the words to describe how much we loved this cake. If I could give it ten stars then I would rate it an 11. I for one am not a huge fan of cake mixes. They always have "the taste". I can detect it a mile away. BUT- cake mixes are great because they are always moist. This wonderful cake was the ONLY chocolate cake recipe that I have made that achieved perfect, perfect moistness. It was perfectly chocolatey, yummy and moist. I will never look around for another chocolate cake recipe again. I have eaten three pieces tonight already and I promised I would stop at one!! I wouldn't change a thing about this recipe!

text:
WOW this cake is so good! But let me explain why I only gave it 4 stars. I followed the directions exactly and then put the batter in two 9 inch cake pans and baked. When I pulled them out both cakes had run over terribly and both cakes fell. It was a complete mess and all of the ingredients had been wasted. After reading all of the reviews I just couldn't believe that no one else had this problem, as I followed the directions exactly. I'm sure the cakes fell b/c there was too much batter in each pan, but that's what the directions said to do, so that's what I did. Anyway, I decided to try it again, b/c I was making it for my husband's bday and I really wanted to make him a cake. So instead I put the batter in a bunt pan and halfed the frosting. The cake was amazing!! And so moist, but VERY rich! Will make again, but only in a bunt pan. Thank you!

text:
WOW! What a rich cake! I admit, adding the boiling water had me concerned but this cake is excellent.  I did not half the layers and simply made a 2 layer cake. And b/c I was short on butter, in the icing I used 1/2 cup margarine and 1/4 cup butter. This is an excellent cake overall. Very moist. The icing was "workable" and I was even able to put some into an icing bag to create borders. I will keep this icing recipe to use for other things also. The name "Extreme Chocolate Cake" fits this recipe!!!

text:
This cake is absolutely delicious - moist and chocolatey.  Just the way I wanted a chocolate cake with chocolate frosting to taste, without being over the top.  My sister and I made this with our kids (ages 6 and 2), and it was so easy to throw everything in the Kitchenaid and let it do the mixing.  I loved that I didn't need a bunch of separate bowls.  The batter was very thin, but the cake layers cooked perfectly.  I just left the two layers intact.  The cake was very crumbly, and presented some challenges to me when I was icing it.  So, it wasn't the most lovely cake I've ever seen, but it was delicious.  I'm keeping this one as my "go to" chocolate cake recipe, unless I can find something just as yummy that doesn't crumble.

text:
Fabulous cake! the cake portion of the recipe is spot on! great texture, great taste! I did make one change. I boiled the water and then let it sit for about 5 minutes before I added it to the mixture.  As for the icing; I changed the recipe to: 1 cup real butter, softened; 3/4 cups unsweetened cocoa powder; 5 1/2 cups confectioner's sugar, 2/3 cups milk, 1 tsp vanilla. the original amount of cocoa powder seemed to much to me, so I added it a bit at a time until I liked the taste, which was about 3/4 cups. Also, I prefer a creamier buttercream so I upped the butter. Thank you for a great recipe. My family and neighbors loved it!

text:
I am re-reviewing this after many, many, many times making this cake.  The batter looks perfect until you add the water - then it turns into a soupy mess and you may be afraid you've ruined it, but stick with it because this is the best chocolate cake ever!  This cake is moist and crumby and the frosting is like an airy, whipped chocolate mousse.  My favorite alteration is to use 1t peppermint extract/1t vanilla extract and top with mint icing and chocolate ganache.  To die for!

text:
If you are looking for the perfect moist and easy to prepare cake look no further!  Ingredients were ones that I had on hand and it came together quickly.  I did substitute 1 cup of coffee for the 1 cup of water bc of personal preference but this is just a common flavor variation.  As others have said do not be alarmed by how watery the mixture is after adding the liquid...it does turn out!  I baked this in 3x 9" pans and was impressed with how big, light and fluffy this cake was!  Gone in a mere 24 hours!  Straight to my favorites for sure!   I think I will add some raspberry flavoring to the frosting next time...

text:
I thought this cake was a disaster.  The cake didn't rise as expected, so I couldn't make 4 layers out of it.  When I tried to take it out of the pans, they stuck horribly to the bottom, creating a huge crumbled mess.  I 'patched' it together with the frosting which turned out very grainy & way too sweet.  I was about to throw it out but my picky 24 yr old son wanted to try a piece. He carried on so much about it, it was almost funny.  He said his stomach said, "what heavenly food stuff did you just feed me?"  He said it was THE BEST cake he had ever eaten & he questioned whether I had actually baked it or really bought it.  He couldn't stop eating it & asked that I make it on a regular basis.   Go figure......maybe I'll give it another shot.  4 stars for winning over my very critical son.

text:
I bake cakes to sell for special occasions.  I baked this for a lady's birthday.  I baked it in 2, 9" square pans.  Instead of the frosting, I made ganache and poured in between the layers and over the top, then made chocolate rectangles and put them around the two layers, for a "basket" look, then filled the top full of dark and white dipped chocolate strawberries, and tied a ribbon around the "basket" to look pretty.  I had wonderful comments about it.  The cake was very moist.   It can even be eaten without any icing or ganache and taste great.

text:
Fudgey delicious!! I made this for Thanksgiving dessert.  I've tried many chocolate cake recipes; this is the best yet.  I followed the recipe exactly except I made the frosting with 1/3 cup half-and-half and 1/3 cup of 1% milk (what I had on hand).  I did have to add a few more tablespoons of milk than the recipe called for.  I always make my own frosting, can't stand the stuff in a can, and I'll definitely use this on my white cakes also.   I suggest trimming off the outer edge of the layers before frosting (easier if you first put it in the freezer for a short while).  I only had a sliver of a piece as some of the relatives (husband included) wanted a second helping..forget about the pumpkin pie!  I've already been asked to bring this to my sister-in-law's at Christmas.
